data.title: UNITED KINGDOM / ITALY: KENNETH BRANAGH'S LATEST FILM, 'IN THE BLEAK MIDWINTER', OPENS IN LONDON
data.meta_description: Search and license clips from Reuters vast archive of news video footage, dating back to 1896
data.text:
Title: UNITED KINGDOM / ITALY: KENNETH BRANAGH'S LATEST FILM, 'IN THE BLEAK MIDWINTER', OPENS IN LONDON

Summary: LONDON, ENGLAND, UNITED KINGDOM (RECENT) (RTV) (CONTAINS FLASH PHOTOGRAPHY) VARIOUS OF CELEBRITIES ARRIVING AT PREMIERE/ ACTOR MICKEY ROURKE

Embargoed: 14th December 1995 12:00

Keywords:

Location: LONDON, UNITED KINGDOM/VENICE, ITALY

City:

Country: EUROPE England United Kingdom Italy

Reuters ID: LVADAY7HJ4ACKF882HROZ8F2AZ2H

Story Text: It's been a difficult year for British actor-director Kenneth Branagh, with a box-office flop and a failed relationship.

But there are signs his new film "In the Bleak Midwinter" could lift the curse that has dogged him for the past 12 months.

Celebrities packed the London premiere of the black-and-white film, which promises to be different from the start.

The story is close to the heart of all actors (not least the Shakespearian Branagh) as a troupe of unemployed, untalented actors try to stage "Hamlet" in an empty church.

The cast includes Richard Briers, Jennifer Saunders, John Sessions and Joan Collins.

Branagh admits it was a low budget production and "everyone was on the same money from the clapper loader to Joan Collins".

Branagh wrote and directed the movie but does not himself appear though Michael Maloney - the moving spirit, the rising star, the Hamlet - looks remarkable like an alter ego.

After the dismal box office failure of his feature "Frankenstein" and his split with long-time companion Emma Thompson, Branagh decided it was time to regroup. He said, "I wanted to make something that made people laugh, I wanted to do it quickly, I wanted to do it with people I knew".

A lavish premiere party hosted by fashion designers Aquascutum attracted various cast members, including Joan Collins.

Other guests included actor Mickey Rourke, former 70's cult model Twiggy and former Rolling Stones band member Bill Wyman. All seemed to agree that Branagh had been successful in his more subdued return to the silver screen.
